into-the-blue.description: Your journey from Into the Blue around the entire museum starts right here!

etruscan.description: Archaeologists haven’t found many examples of blue items made in the Etruscan world, but there are some objects in this gallery that turned blue over time.

greece.description: See if you can find the tiny blue vessels in a gallery of mostly red and black pottery!

rome.description: Ancient Roman glass vessels held oils and perfumes. Some of these were originally blue, while others have developed a blue patina over time.

eastern-mediterranean.description: This gallery houses blue pigments and objects that sailed long distances for trade at ports around the Mediterranean Sea.

asia.description: Blues in this gallery are hiding in plain sight!

egypt.description: There were a range of blue hues in ancient Egypt, made in lots of creative ways. Can you find the shiny blues we call faience?

middle-east.description: Archaeologists found a plethora of blue in the Middle East. See examples from early history that are carved from lapis lazuli. Later cultures used bright blue glaze to decorate pottery and tile.

north-america.description: Spot the beautiful variety of blues decorating the clothing and objects from North America!

mexico-central-america.description: Most blue color has faded from objects found in Mexico & Central America, but one turquoise object  in this gallery remains bright blue!

africa.description: Blue materials appear in many forms across the African continent. Check out the ways they’re incorporated into art and fashion!

assyria.description: The Assyrian Empire used blue to communicate wealth, decadence, and power. Blue paints and pigments decorated the halls of palaces and adorned the elite.
